fields.description:
Original summary: "Batched mail too slow, unbatched mail too noisy."

We recently upgraded from 2.12 to 4.5 and our users are complaining because the batch feature, which they were looking forward to, significantly slows down mail delivery (they're stuck with either getting mail slowly or getting feedback which is later removed and having it dribble in.

As mentioned in BSERV-2839, what they'd like is for the mail to be delivered immediately, but only after the reviewer has finished reviewing (preferably, a single mail that includes all the feedback, rather than multiple mails).

The goals are:
* a reviewers comments should not arrive before they're finished reviewing all the code
* minimize email
* mail should arrive as fast as possible after the reviewer has finished reviewing the code
* comments which are later found to be incorrect and are removed by the reviewer should not generate mail
fields.summary: Consider more actively flushing email batch on "needs work" or "approved"

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Java 8 update 20 has introduced an additional flag for the G1 garbage collector that enables string deduplication to lower the memory footprint of the JVM. The functionality can be enabled by adding the {{-XX:+UseStringDeduplication}} JVM flag.

More information about this parameter can be found in the following links:
- [https://blogs.oracle.com/java-platform-group/entry/g1_from_garbage_collector_to]
- [http://java-performance.info/java-string-deduplication/]
- [https://blog.codecentric.de/en/2014/08/string-deduplication-new-feature-java-8-update-20-2/]

h3. Suggested Solution
Evaluate adding this parameter by default, as it is said not to cause significant performance overhead, however it can save additional heap memory, asynchronously to GC cycles.
fields.summary: Enable string deduplication by default

fields.description:
We’d like to be able to provide a role for our development teams that allow them to do things like create repositories, branches, and fork repositories while inheriting security permissions (e.g. branch permissions) from the master project and not be able to modify those permissions on these objects.

This would allow permissions to be managed at the project level by a separate "Security" team while allowing developers freedom to create and organize repositories and forks for their needs without violating upstream security requirements.
fields.summary: New permissions group which can create repositories with only inherited permissions

h3. Summary
UPM prevents the Bitbucket Server to complete the startup process when the network connection only allows outbound connections.
During the startup process, the UPM tries to connect to the internet and can successfully establish a connection, however it never receives a communication back and this prevents the spring context to load completely.

h3. Expected Results
The application can successfully load regardless of the network connection availability.

h3. Actual Results
The "Started Bitbucket Japanese (Japan) Language Pack" message is presented in the Bitbucket Server user interface and, even after some time, the login page is not displayed to the users.

fields.description:
In Stash 3.7, code was added which automatically reenables {{gc.auto}} when a repository has no forks. The intent was to undo the GC changes made when a repository is forked when the last fork was deleted, and that works well.

However, some instances have repositories which trigger GC frequently, or for which GC frequently fails (usually due to pull request refs being updated). For such instances, the code to automatically reenable {{gc.auto}} effectively eliminates the simplest way an administrator could work around the error.

Rather than just always reenabling {{gc.auto}} when a repository has no forks, instead we should reenable it only when {{gc.pruneexpire=never}} is also set. Our forking code always sets both, so we can use that as a reliable mechanism for determining whether we're reverting fork GC changes or a repository administrator has disabled auto GC.
fields.summary: Don't automatically re-enable gc.auto when gc.pruneexpire isn't set

fields.description:
{panel:title=Atlassian status as of May 2021|borderStyle=solid|borderColor=#deebff|titleBGColor=#deebff|bgColor=#ffffff}
Hi everyone,

Thanks for your feedback and advocacy on this suggestion. [Bitbucket Data Center 7.13|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/bitbucket-data-center-and-server-7-13-release-notes-1056675425.html] introduces Description templates that allow you to set a custom template for the description field which populates when creating a Pull request. Project admins will be able to create and manage the description template. We are looking into the ability to allow template creation at the repository level for future releases. You can read more details [here|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/create-a-pull-request-808488431.html].

Please give it a try and let us know your feedback in a comment below.

Thanks,
Sam Power - Engineering Manager
Bitbucket Data Center
{panel}

When we go to make a pull request our team uses a template to make our QA process go more smoothly. It would be nice if we had a feature where we could setup each project to have a default PR template that's auto-populated into the comment box when you go to create the PR so we don't have to copy/paste it in every time.
fields.summary: PR Templates

When in a pull request's diff view with multiple files, selecting a file with percentage character in filename prevents from choosing other files after that. To reproduce:
1) create a new pull request with several files and at least one has percentage in filename.
2) open pull request's diff view in browser.
3) select a file with percentage character in filename.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When upgrading to Bitbucket 4.2 or greater, one of the database operations involves renaming a column. Oracle DB's have a feature called Extended Statistics which creates virtual columns based on regular columns, and this feature, if enabled, will prevent the DB upgrade from renaming regular columns that are used in virtual columns.

h3. Workaround
Users can manually disable extended statistics or drop virtual columns themselves, then proceed with the upgrade, as per [Database Upgrade Error: column to be renamed is used in a virtual column expression|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServerKB/Database+Upgrade+Error%3A+column+to+be+renamed+is+used+in+a+virtual+column+expression]

h3. Suggested Solution
Wrap schema updates with logic to drop/create extended statistics / virtual columns. More info can be found in [ORA-54033 and the Hidden Virtual Column Mystery|https://blogs.oracle.com/sql/entry/ora_54033_and_the_hidden]
fields.summary: Support Oracle RDBMS with Extended Statistics enabled

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Loading a Pull Request activity screen fails to load and produces an error when the customer has large comments added that contain a hexadecimal number between 7 and 40 characters. Even if the comment is contained within a code-block.

This is further exacerbated if the repository contains a large number of commits. This can cause the database to spike in an attempt to search for and link the 'commit like' characters ultimately taking longer than 60 seconds to process causing the frontend JS to time out.

h3. Steps to Reproduce

# Produce large comments that contain 'commit-like' hexadecimal characters wrapped within a code-block.
# Repository with large commit history

h3. Expected Results

The comments are loaded with no issue. Commit hashes are linked appropriately. 

h3. Actual Results
The user receives the following error withing the UI:
{noformat}
Server Unreachable 
The server didn't respond. You may retry your request when the server comes back up.
{noformat}
 
h3.Workaround

No workaround at this time.
fields.summary: Slow performance when rendering comments which contain a large number of commit hashes

fields.description:
Currently, for a reviewer of a Pull Request, there is no way to specify that they have completed the review (provided the comments) and are waiting for further changes from the submitter before the PR can be approved. 

The only options are "approve" or "decline" - which do not capture the work flow completely. 

Would be great to have this intermediate state through which:
 * the reviewer can clearly communicate that he has completed the review of the PR in its current form
 * that the reviewer is waiting for further changes from the submitter before the PR can be approved.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Add ability to mark a Pull Request review as "waiting for further changes" or something similar

fields.description:
The *Changes without a pull request* branch permission blocks Bamboo *Branch merging* without a pull request or message.

*Steps to Reproduce*
# Connect Bitbucket Server to Bamboo Server
# Connect a Bamboo Plan to a Bitbucket Repository
# In Bamboo's plan configuration, enable *Plan Branches*
# On a branch, select *Branch merging enabled* (GateKeeper) to a _target branch_
# In Bitbucket branch management, enable the branch permission *Changes without a pull request* to that same _target branch_
# In git, create a commit that would trigger the GateKeeper merge
*Outcome* The build is marked as broken with no other messages, no pull request is made in Bitbucket to handle the issue.
*Expected Outcome* Bamboo should create a pull request for the broken build due to the permission setting. A link to this pull request should appear in Bamboo
*Expected Outcome Alternative* Bamboo should be allowed to push to the branch regardless of the setting
*Expected Outcome Alternative* There should be a checkbox in branch permissions that allows Bamboo to override this permission setting, while retaining it for other users
fields.summary: Branch permission for pull requests also prevents Bamboo branch merging

fields.description:
In pull requests, it is difficult to know who is the active participant - the author or the reviewers.

The new ability of a reviewer to mark as "Needs work" greatly improves this, but it still isn't clear when the author has finished responding to comments and is ready for the reviewers to look again.

A "Wait for feedback" button or something similar would be good in order to pass over responsibility to the reviewer. Clicking this would send a notification to the reviewers immediately (before, no notifaction would be sent - unless some time has passed with no activity). Would be particularly useful when first annotating a review, or responding to a number of comments.
fields.summary: Add "Wait for feedback" button to change active participant in PR

fields.description:
It would be really useful to be able to have a download button when viewing a file on the section. For a large repo sometimes you only need one file and it would be useful to be able just download that file.
If that could be also done for repository sub folders that would be great.
fields.summary: download single file from git repository

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently when a repository is forked in Bitbucket, garbage collection gets disabled by adding {{pruneexpire = never}} in the {{config}} file.
However, even when all forks from the repository are deleted (i.e. the repositories that were created as a result of forking), the {{pruneexpire}} entry is not removed from the config file.

h3. Suggested Solution

When the last repository that was created by forking from another repository is deleted, the original repository's garbage collection configuration should be reverted to the original state.
fields.summary: As an administrator I want garbage collection to be re-enabled for a repository when all forks from it are deleted

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently Bitbucket's garbage collection behaviour and configuration is somewhat non-transparent. For instance it's not possible to tell which repositories have garbage collection enabled at all and which don't. Similarly it's not possible to manually start garbage collection on a repository from Bitbucket.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Bitbucket should give administrators more control over garbage collection policies and the execution of it, and also show administrators which repositories do have garbage collection enabled and which don't (for instance because they have been forked).
fields.summary: As an administrator I want to have control over garbage collection in Bitbucket

fields.description: When a user creates a new branch via the UI, it should reject it if it has special characters in it. If user is pushing a new branch from command line should reject the push if it has special character in branch name.
fields.summary: Prevent branches being created with special characters

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When running the Bitbucket Server installer as a user other than root, if the supplied home directory is not owned by that user and the user does not have write permissions but has read and execute, the installation fails without an error.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a home directory that is owned by root
# Give the home directory 755 permissions
# Run the installer as a different user (reproduced with user "atlassian"), and give it this home directory
# Continue with default options, and agree to Install

h3. Expected Results
An error such as "{{You have no write permissions for the directory}}", which is given when the user has no permissions at all to the home directory. If the directory permissions are changed to 700 instead of 755, the installer does throw this error.

h3. Actual Results
The user sees the following before the installer exits:
{code}Extracting files ...
                                                                           
Rolling back changes ...{code}

h3.Workaround
Two possible workarounds:
# Give the user running the installer write permissions to the home directory.
# Run the installer as root.
fields.summary: Improve Bitbucket Server installer error reporting when home directory permissions are insufficient

fields.description: Add the ability for administrators to specify enforceable branch naming rules.
fields.summary: Add Enforceable Custom Branch Naming Rules

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Server, clicking on {{Administration | Analytics}} and setting Analytics to Disabled does not actually stop the  Analytics from being gathered and sent to the server from the client.  Rather it seems that this only disables the storing and forwarding of analytics data.  

Many financial, health care, defense & other industries have strict rules on the types of data that can be transferred even within their own networks and it would be best if analytics is disabled, the actual collection of the data should stop, not just the storage of that data on the server and the transfer of the data to Atlassian.

To completely stop the collection of data you can disable the Analytics Client plugin.  And while this does seem to stop the transfer of any analytics data (as seen in Chrome's Developer Tools), this also removes the Analytics item from the Administration page.

h3. Steps to Duplicate:
# In Bitbucket Server, Click Administration | Analytics
# Choose Disabled and then click Save
# From a client system (using Chrome), open Development Tools, choose Network "tab", then filter by the string "bulk"
# Login to Bitbucket and traverse to a few different pages
# Note the reference to Bitbucket Analytics

h3. Work Around:
# In Bitbucket Server, Click Administration | Manage Plugins
# Change the filter to System
# Locate and disable the Analytics Client plugin
# From a client system (using Chrome), open Development Tools, choose Network "tab", then filter by the string "bulk"
# Login to Bitbucket and traverse to a few different pages
# Note the reference to Bitbucket Analytics are no longer seen.

The Analytics Client plugin should not have to be disabled for the transfer, collection and forwarding of analytics data to be completely disabled.  When the Sys Admins chose for Analytics to be disabled, it should no longer show any analytics data being sent from the client.
fields.summary: Disabled Analytics still shows analytics data being sent to server from the client

fields.description:
Copied the text of Issue BB-13100



It should be possible to edit/change the pull request author.

Use case: When a developer has signaled (e.g., via JIRA issue status) that a branch is ready for review but forgotten to create a pull request, the reviewer should be able to create a pull request and then change its author to the developer. Without the ability to edit, the reviewer has to pick from two or three bad options:

    delay the review until the developer creates a pull request (may take a few days!)
    create a pull request with reviewer as an author, which allows the review to proceed but screws up subsequent interaction in many ways
    review the branch without creating a pull request, which means review comments are going to be attached to individual branch commits (among other problems).
fields.summary: Ability to change the author of a pull request

fields.description:
If you select an upgrade installation, but the existing service is not found (by checking for the presence of {{/etc/init.d/atlbitbucket}} or {{/etc/init.d/atlstash}}), then even if you select the option to "Install as a service" the option will be silently turned off, and the service will not be installed and the {{atlbitbucket}} user not created if upgrading from pre-4.0

In this scenario we should probably warn the user that they want to upgrade a service installation, but the existing service was not found, and if they elect to continue they will need to clean up the existing service manually as we will not be able to uninstall it for them.
fields.summary: Using the Linux installer, behaviour is unexpected if user is upgrading and existing service not found

Please advise us about this inconvenient.
Is this restricted value defined in the code (hardcoded)? Or is it in the DB? Can it be change?

fields.description:
Using transcrypt git extension is great to hide some files content for some people.
It works great for local repo which have transcrypt enable.

Encrypted file, is a good way/workaround to replace the folder permissions which are present in Centralized SCM, like SVN/Perforce. It's not exactly the same feature, but it quite similar if you just have two type of access/permissions for files in your depot.
And it's far easier to used than having multiple repos with submodule/subtree.

But when the files are push to Bitbucket server, it's not possible to view the encrypted files, because there is no clean/smudge hook on the server, like there is a local repo.

Viewing this encryptedfile will be great for using diff feature on Bitbucket server, but also (and especially) to comment modified encrypted file inside Pull request.

Here the feature have the plugin could do:
* view the encrypted file content in PullRequest
* view the encrypted file content in diff view
* view the encrypted file content in the standard content view
* have a setting by repo to define the transcrypt password that will be used to decrypt the file, and a permission/rights setting with a list of users/groups that will be able to view the encrypted file on this depot using the given password.
fields.summary: Create a transcrypt addons for crypted files

fields.description:
Add possibility to set default type of diff for images (Two-up, blend, split, pixeldiff)
When reviewing PR that contains alot of images I usually want to see either pixeldiff or split so i can easily see the differences in the images. Two-up is propably the worst image diff to see exactly what changed.

I would appreciate either some settings in profile or the selection being "permanent" for atleast one pullrequest (or rather one webpage reload) - if i select pixeldiff once, it will remember this choice.

Thanks
fields.summary: Add possibility to set default type of diff for images (Two-up, blend, split, pixeldiff)

fields.description:
During startup of Bitbucket Server there exists a small window where incoming Git hosting operations via SSH can become deadlocked. Although only SSH connections can cause the deadlock, the resulting exhaustion of hosting tickets may result in other requests, for example those via HTTP, becoming blocked.

Symptoms will include:
* Git hosting operations (e.g. clone, pull, push) may become blocked and fail after (by default) 300 seconds
* Users accessing the Web UI may see, in a banner, the warning "Bitbucket Server is reaching resource limits"
* The {{atlassian-bitbucket.log}} file may contain warnings such as "A \[scm-hosting\] ticket could not be acquired (0/12)"

Note: This bug describes a problem that occurs during startup, with symptoms occurring immediately following startup. It would be easy to confuse these symptoms with [normal hosting ticket exhaustion that can occur under high load|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserverkb/bitbucket-server-is-reaching-resource-limits-779171381.html].

*Solution*
Upgrade to a version containing the fix

*Workaround*
Restarting Bitbucket Server on the affected instance is required. The window in which incoming SSH requests can be impacted by this is very small, typically only a few seconds. A system under heavy sustained load will be more susceptible to this problem and it may become necessary to block incoming network connections (to port 7999, the default Bitbucket Server SSH port) in order for the instance to start correctly.
fields.summary: SCM cache deadlock during startup (SSH only)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a plugin using the decorator
# Create a pull request
# Load the decorated page

h3. Expected Results

The page looks like the other pull request pages.

h3. Actual Results

The pull request header is missing.
 
h3. Notes

Example usage: ([bitbucket-example-plugin|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/bitbucket-example-plugin/src/a55cffe7744e8f50abcd2f092243b4f7e1d855b1/src/main/resources/templates/templates.soy?at=master&fileviewer=file-view-default#templates.soy-84])

fields.description:
After forking a repository in another project, when creating a branch from a JIRA issue the issue will not update anything under the development tab.

Steps to Recreate
1.) Fork a repository from another team project
2.) Create a new branch from a JIRA issue 
3.) Observe the issue does not update its development section
4.) Create a commit on that new branch that links to the JIRA issue
5.) Observe the commit information populates the JIRA issue but the branch does not.

Smart Commits do not work in this scenario as well.
fields.summary: Jira does not pick up branches in forked repositories until forced to check

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
The mail notification settings are not stored in a configuration property, and it is not possible to easily disable them.

*Use cases for this request*
+Disaster recovery daily synchronization+
Every day a backup of the production instance is copied to a disaster recovery site. When the application is started in the disaster recovery environment, the batch emails (not yet processed) are sent from both the main production and the disaster recovery environment causing duplicated emails to be received.

+Mirroring a production system to a development/staging server+
We have a staging server that we use to test updates to Bitbucket Server. We clone from production but don't want the staging clone to send (duplicate) emails.

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a configuration property to disable the mail notification, so that this setting can be set independently on the main production and on the disaster recovery site.

+JIRA+ provides the {{-Datlassian.mail.senddisabled=true}} option.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to easily disable mail notifications with a configuration property

fields.description: Our Bitbucket server license is granted to 1000 users. However, we don't have a means of auditing the last time a user who has been licensed and actually used the service within the last 90-days. I've been drilling through the MySQL Bitbucket database to find a query with needed results. Can this request be built into the System Admin GUI to query an repository activity based on x days?
fields.summary: Bitbucket User Activity Query Ability to Manage License Usage

h3. Problem Definition
At this moment, if Bitbucket is using JIRA for user management then the JIRA user directory is "Read only" in Bitbucket. If a user tried to reset his password in Bitbucket, he gets a message :

"User directory is read-only" 
 !bitbucket.png|thumbnail! 


h3. Suggested Solution
Instead of the message, the user should be redirected to the JIRA reset password page and should be able to reset his password. 

h3. Workaround 
At the moment, user needs to navigate to JIRA and try to reset the password there.
fields.summary: Using JIRA for user management and resetting password, should redirect to JIRA redirect page.

fields.description:
The job scheduler available to plugins in Stash and Bitbucket Server versions up to and including 4.5 has been implemented using [Quartz|http://www.quartz-scheduler.org/], and from Stash 3.2 onwards has used Hazelcast to store its job and trigger information.  This can incur serialisation and deserialisation costs and delays when Hazelcast partition operation threads are very heavily loaded or in clustered instances affected by network partitions. 

From Bitbucket Server 4.6 onwards the job scheduler no longer uses Quartz and Hazelcast, but is implemented using [Atlassian Caesium|https://bitbucket.org/atlassian/caesium] which is much simpler and not subject to the same costs and delays under similar conditions.
fields.summary: Replace HazelcastJobStore-backed Quartz scheduler with atlassian Caesium scheduler

fields.description: Make the pull requests table sortable.
fields.summary: Make the pull requests table sortable.

fields.description:
The {{OsgiSafeStreamSerializer}} that is used to safely serialize/deserialize objects provided by plugins as they're stored / loading in Hazelcast is quite slow. 

Investigation into why this is slow traced back to Hazelcast's {{ClassLoaderUtil#loadClass}} which first tries to load using the current ClassLoader and only considers the context ClassLoader when that fails.

The {{OsgiSafeStreamSerializer}} uses the context ClassLoader to the make the OSGI Bundle's classes visible to the serialization  mechanism. It therefore pays the penalty of frequent class loading failures. Since {{ClassLoader#loadClass}} uses internal locking, this introduces a bottleneck under high load.
fields.summary: Improve performance of OsgiSafeStreamSerializer

fields.description:
When switching beteween the "Diff" and the "commits" tabs on the "Compare" screen, you get a spinner. However, data isn't actually loaded. You have to manually hit reload on the page to get the latest commits, if any have been added since you first visited the page.

*Reporter*: James French
*E-mail*: [mailto:jafrench@atlassian.com]
fields.summary: Compare view should refresh diff/comments when tab switches

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Project administrators can grant permissions to any group as described on the [Using project permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucketserver/using-project-permissions-776639801.html] page.

This may be an issue when it is required to allow the flexibility to grant the project admin permissions to a wider number of users (project administrators), but it is not expected that "not authorized" groups are added by mistake to a project by them.

h3. Suggested Solution
Restrict the groups that can be granted permissions based on configurable rules (e.g. the first n letters of the name of the repository have to match the first n letters of the name of the group).

h3. Workaround
*Limited number of Repository administrators*
Limit the number of users that are allowed to change repository permissions (Repository administrators), so that the permission settings is centralized.

*Grant permissions using REST APIs*
Implement the desired custom logic by using a [Bitbucket Server REST APIs|https://developer.atlassian.com/static/rest/bitbucket-server/4.5.1/bitbucket-rest.html].
This alternative can be combined with the previous option, and allow more control on the permitted groups.
fields.summary: As an admin, I want to be able to restrict the subset of groups that can be granted permissions on a project/repository

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
'Delete' and 'edit' buttons in Bitbucket Server tables are only visible when hovering over the line. This means that they are not accessible when using tabs to navigate.

The following features are *not accessible* unless the line is selected:
- Removing existing "Access keys" for a repository
- Removing users from the settings
fields.summary: Unable to focus on delete or edit buttons in a table when using tabs to navigate

fields.description:
When I use com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.pull.MergeRequest public method:
 
{{public void veto (String summaryMessage, String detailedMessage)}} 

I noticed that if I use HTML tags in the detailedMessage it will render the HTML in the modal window that appears when the Merge button is clicked, however if there is only 1 veto then the tooltip that appears when hovering over the Merge button will display the detailedMessage including HTML tags. If there are multiple vetos, it will say "This pull request can't be merged. Click for details." 

I think if there is only 1 veto, the tooltip should display the summaryMessage, followed by "Click for more details." which opens the modal window and displays the detailedMessage. This would avoid the ugly exposing of HTML, provided that there is no HTML in the summaryMessage.
fields.summary: MergeRequest veto will display HTML tags in Merge button tooltip

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In the repository permissions page, if you add a group, this will be displayed in all lowercase in the UI, even though the group name may contain uppercase characters.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group in Bitbucket Server in uppercase characters. (i.e. TEST)
# Add this group as a repository permission to a repository. 
# It will display in all lowercase. (i.e. test)

h3. Expected Results
The group name should be displayed in its correct case in the UI.

h3. Actual Results
The group name is displayed in all lowercase.

h3. Notes
This also affects the output of the REST API endpoints to retrieve the permissions at repository and project level.
Groups retrieved using the {{rest/api/1.0/admin/groups}} instead are not impacted.
fields.summary: Group Names in Repository Permissions are Displaying in Lowercase and being returned in Lowercase by the REST API endpoints

h3. Notes
Adverse affects can also be seen by re-using project keys.

h3.Workaround
Rename the project on the primary server to one that has not been used before. Smart mirroring will continue to work after this.
fields.summary: Renaming Project to Name of Deleted Project Breaks Smart Mirroring

fields.description:
Stash when you have branching configured and auto-merge enabled; if there is a merge conflict  it creates a new merge conflict pull request with the name 'Automatic merge failure'  Any new auto-merge failures get tacked on to this pull request.  Also there isn't a way to get in and add anything to resolve the merge conflicts. fields.description:
Hi 

We are using stash v3.8.0

Read / Write default permission in a project in stash makes the project globally available to all non-admin/admin users. This is a security breach as users who are not a part of a project can also read / write that project . 
The Stash User doesn't know the impact of Write or Read permission. So if stash-user makes the project's default permission as Write or Read , then project gets globally visible.
Can atlassian removes the Default permission ( Write / Read / No access) part from the permission page and allow permission only through User and Group access . See image (Default.png)
fields.summary: Default permission ( Write / Read /No Access ) part should be removed from project permission page of stash
I liked the detailed example, this page helped me ...

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

It often happens that a user outside the team requires repository access for a limited period of time (i.e. temporary consultants, interns).

Bitbucket does not have such a model. Once granted, the permissions are kept unless manually removed. 

h3. Suggested Solution

It would be nice to have the possibility to remove granted Bitbucket repo/project permission given time of period, without removing it manually.
 !Screen Shot 2016-04-08 at 10.17.51.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Workaround 
In case Bitbucket is configured to use an external directory such as LDAP, a possible workaround is to set up an expiry date for the user account so that after the account is locked the user would not be able to connect to Bitbucket anymore.
fields.summary: As an administrator I would like to be able to set up temporary permissions for users

fields.description:
I'm not sure if this is the right project for this, so please resort as necessary!

Something that i'm finding extremely frustrating with many code review tools is that there are just too many files in the list (example: github will truncate and give up if there are more than x number of files).  This feature request is for bitbucket's recently mentioned improved code review tools to allow filtering of the files being displayed in the diff.

ideally i'd like to key in on specific source files based on file type or a wildcard, or combination of the two. *.h, *.m *.swift and not include things like *.png, *.jpg, *.strings.

Thanks!
fields.summary: codereview filetype filter

fields.description:
Currently Bitbucket does not immediately terminate active sessions (to the website or for active git operations) when a users permissions are removed.

Steps to Duplicate:
- User X is logged into Bitbucket and is browsing repositories, adding comments, etc. 
- User X is removed from either Crowd, LDAP, AD, or even directly in Bitbucket
- Problem 1 is that if the user is LDAP or AD Bitbucket may not know about the permissions changing until a synchronization (by default 60 minutes)
- Problem 2 is that even after LDAP/AD synchronization, User X is not automatically logged out of Bitbucket and they are not prevented from accessing anything they had permission to access until they are required to login again (do to timeout or closing the browser).

Some industries that are highly regulated require the ability to immediately terminate access.  

Some possible suggestions include:
- A page available to System Admins that shows all current sessions, with the ability to terminate sessions from the UI
- A REST API that could be called either manually or from LDAP to terminate sessions opened by a user whose permissions were removed
fields.summary: Provide capability to immediately prevent a user from accessing Bitbucket if their permissions are removed

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Bitbucket Server using ldaps makes clone perform slower than using ldap

That happens because Embedded Crowd does not pool LDAP connections. Reference:
- [CWD-4070|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CWD-4070]


h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Install BBS
# Link it to an LDAP server using {{ldaps}}
# Link it to an LDAP server using {{ldap}}

It is much faster using {{ldap}}.

h3. Expected Results
There shouldn't be such difference.

h3. Actual Results
This is a typical authentication over {{ldaps}} on {{atlassian-bitbucket-profile.log}} file. Notice it takes 8 seconds:
{noformat}
2016-03-21 00:02:38,309 | http-nio-7990-exec-7 | *5PJ9S7x2x147120x0 | XXXXX | -
[7346ms] - "GET /scm/beg/beg_test.git/info/refs HTTP/1.1"
[7048ms] - Authentication org.springframework.security.authentication.AuthenticationProvider.authenticate(Authentication)
[4ms] - attemptAuthentication - com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-crowd-sso:crowdSsoAuthHandler
[2ms] - CaptchaTicket com.atlassian.stash.internal.user.CaptchaService.checkCaptcha(String,CaptchaResponse)
[7039ms] - attemptAuthentication - com.atlassian.bitbucket.server.bitbucket-authentication:crowdHttpAuthHandler
[7039ms] - ApplicationUser com.atlassian.stash.internal.user.CaptchaService.authenticateWithCaptcha(CaptchaTicket,UncheckedOperation)
[7039ms] - ApplicationUser com.atlassian.bitbucket.user.UserService.authenticate(String,String)
[4ms] - InternalNormalUser com.atlassian.stash.internal.user.StashUserDao.loadUser(User)
[4ms] - Page com.atlassian.bitbucket.user.UserService.findGroupsByUser(String,PageRequest)
[3ms] - InternalRepository com.atlassian.stash.internal.repository.RepositoryDao.getBySlug(String,String)
[5ms] - Page com.atlassian.bitbucket.user.UserService.findGroupsByUser(String,PageRequest)
[4ms] - boolean com.atlassian.bitbucket.scm.ScmRequestCheckService.checkActionAllowed(ScmRequest)
[1ms] - boolean com.atlassian.bitbucket.license.LicenseService.canLogin(Principal)
[6ms] - Ticket com.atlassian.bitbucket.throttle.ThrottleService.acquireTicket(String)
[268ms] - /opt/stash/installs/git/bin/git http-backend
{noformat}
 
Thread dumps taken during the same period are stuck in the SSL handshake:
{noformat}
"http-nio-7990-exec-8" #266 daemon prio=5 os_prio=0 tid=0x00007f6be0074800 nid=0x5cd5 runnable [0x00007f6bcd2a5000]
   java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE

	- locked <0x00000000eb1a56d0> (a java.lang.Object)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.startHandshake(SSLSocketImpl.java:1403)
	at sun.security.ssl.SSLSocketImpl.startHandshake(SSLSocketImpl.java:1387)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.Connection.createSocket(Connection.java:376)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.Connection.<init>(Connection.java:203)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapClient.<init>(LdapClient.java:137)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapClient.getInstance(LdapClient.java:1613)
	at com.sun.jndi.ldap.LdapCtx.connect(LdapCtx.java:2746)

	at javax.naming.ldap.InitialLdapContext.<init>(InitialLdapContext.java:154)
	at org.springframework.ldap.core.support.LdapContextSource.getDirContextInstance(LdapContextSource.java:42)

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently in the Bitbucket Server web UI the server's SSH host key is only displayed in MD5 format, however modern SSH clients display the server's host key in SHA256 format. It's therefore nigh impossible for a user to verify the server's identify, which poses a security risk.
h3. Suggested Solution

In the web UI the SHA256 version of the host key should be displayed alongside the MD5 version.
h3. Workarounds
 # Either, set the option
 {{  FingerprintHash md5}}
 in the SSH configuration file on the client to see the MD5 hash, but this applies to all hosts, which may not be desirable.
 # Or, if you want to avoid the global configuration change, you can also configure MD5 hashes on a case by case basis:
 {{  GIT_SSH_COMMAND="ssh -o FingerprintHash=MD5" git ...}}
fields.summary: Bitbucket Web UI should display host key in MD5 and SHA256 format

fields.description:
My group used Code Collaborator with a different SCM before switching over to Git and Bitbucket.  In Collaborator, in addition to comments a reviewer can create an "issue" on any line of code, and until the issue is resolved then the review cannot be completed.  This is used to ensure that all reviewers' feedback gets addressed and nothing is inadvertently missed.

The Bitbucket "Tasks" are similar to issues in Collaborator but there are some things preventing them from being as useful (in order of priority):

1.  Need to enforce that only a reviewer (not the original code author or any subsequent contributors) can close the task.  Alternatively, only allow the creator of a task to close it.
 - If this is difficult to implement, at a minimum need to send an email notification to the creator of the task when someone closes it so they can verify that their feedback was in fact addressed.

2.  Better association of a task/comment with a file.  Today when a file is updated the comments/tasks can become disconnected from the file, which is frustrating and adds needless searching or even lost work entirely.  In this situation perhaps instead show all disconnected comments aggregated at the top of the file (or even convert them to file comments).  A further enhancement would be to allow entering a line number for each one to move it back to the specified line.

3.  Allow comments/tasks on any line of code, not just near the changed ones.  Not sure why this restriction is in place?  It is quite often the case that a code change will have ramifications on code more than 10 lines away from the modified code.

Note that currently we're using Stash 3.11 so my apologies if any of the above has already been addressed in a later version, and if so please let me know and I will bug our IT department to update!
fields.summary: Add rigor to PR Tasks to make them more useful

fields.description:
I'm not sure if this is still persistent in newer versions of Stash/Bitbucket, but this just happened on 3.9.1:

If a user sets up a pull request, then force pushes it to be the exact same as the destination branch, Stash thinks that it was remotely merged, and marks the pull request as merged.

I understand why it thinks it's remotely merged, however the force push isn't reflected in the pull request, and it seems like the commits that are present in the PR actually made it to the destination branch, when in fact it's not actually true.

To repeat the bug:
1. Create a branch *dev/test* with multiple commits
2. Submit *dev/test* for a PR, to merge to *master*
3. Execute 'git reset --hard origin/master on *dev/test*
4. Execute 'git push origin dev/test --force'

The result will be that the PR created in step 2 will be 'Remotely Merged', yet it will not contain the action of removing commits (via the force push)
fields.summary: Force push bug related to 'remote merge'

fields.description:
We use the custom http-auth-handler mechanism described here:

https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/server/docs/latest/reference/plugin-module-types/http-authentication-handler.html

On the mirror server, it calls out to /rest/mirroring/1.0/authenticate to delegate authentication to the upstream server. On the upstream server, the resource handler for this method calls com.atlassian.bitbucket.internal.mirroring.upstream.auth.AuthenticationService.authenticateForUser() which calls com.atlassian.bitbucket.internal.mirroring.upstream.auth.DefaultAuthenticationService.authenticateForUser() which calls crowdControl.authenticate(). This effectively bypasses the http-auth-handler capability.

In our case, we have two different types of usernames. One which is the one most people know and remember, that is related to their email address, and one which is an internal form that is permanently unique. Normally we use http-auth-handler to recognize both of these, and return the right ApplicationUser whether they login with one form or the other. You can think of this similar to how your jira.atlassian.com site allows users to login with their email address but once logged in you can clearly see that the backend username used in JIRA is something different.

Now that we are trying to use the Smart Mirror capability, it doesn't work when using "http://USERNAME@MIRROR/..." when the user uses the form they know and remember. It only works when the USERNAME is the same as the backend username form. The http-auth-handler has no effect.

I did try to put our http-auth-handler on the mirror by adding the plugin to the bitbucket-data/shared/plugins/installed-plugins directory, but that made them both fail. After some investigation, it seems this is because it needs to implement the "internal" DelegatedHttpAuthenticationHandler which also seems problematic to pursue.

For now, I am thinking that we can recommend users use SSH on the mirror when they need to authenticate, and HTTPS on the mirror for anonymous access (important new feature in Bitbucket 4.4.2, thanks!). However, there may be cases where they still want to use HTTPS on the mirror with authentication, and requiring them to be aware of their backend username when this requirement does not exist on the upstream server, will be confusing for users.
fields.summary: Delegated HTTP authentication from mirror server to upstream server does not honor http-auth-handler mechanism

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

In Bitbucket there's no way of knowing whether the target branch of a pull request was changed since the pull request was created or not.

Take the following situation:

# User A commits and pushes changes to their own branch
# User A creates a pull request
# A build is run to verify whether the {{master}} build would still pass if the pull request was merged
# User B pushes their own changes to {{master}}
# User A does not know that {{master}} was changed

You have the option of requiring a successful build before being allowed to merge a pull request, but that build runs before User B makes their changes, so effectively there's no way of knowing that merging User A's pull request will not break the {{master}} build.

In situations like this GitHub provides a visual cue to indicate that the target branch was modified since the pull request was created.

h3. Suggested Solution

A visual cue should be displayed on the pull request if the target branch was changed since the time the pull request was created. 

h3. Workaround

There is no known workaround.
fields.summary: As a user I want to be able to see if the target branch of a pull request was changed since the pull request was created

fields.description:
On [Automatic branch merging documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Automatic+branch+merging] we write:
{quote}
h3. Conditions for automatic merging
The following conditions must be satisfied for Bitbucket Server to be able to automatically cascade changes:
- The Bitbucket Server [branching model|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BitbucketServer/Using+branches+in+Bitbucket+Server#UsingbranchesinBitbucketServer-model] must be configured for the repository.
- The 'release' branch type must be enabled or a 'production' branch must be set for the repository.
- The merge must go via a pull request.
- The pull request must be made to a branch that is of the 'release' type or the 'production' branch.
- The target branch of the pull request must have branches that are newer than it.
- Note that Bitbucket Server expects that the 'development' branch (commonly the 'default' branch) is always ahead of any 'release' branches. The final merge in the automatic cascade will be to the 'development' branch.
{quote}

However, it'd be nice if we clarified what our code actually does and tie it back to the Git Workflow. Here is a possibility:
{quote}
Looking at the code, here's what we do:
- If you a PR is merging into a *release* branch, then the merge will be cascaded all the way to the newest release branch and then to the *development* branch as well.
- If you a PR is merging into a *production* branch, then the automatic merge will only be done to the *development* branch. This is done in accordance with the [Gitflow workflow|https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow]

Basically we never merge anything into the *production* branch. The reason for this is that in [Gitflow workflow|https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow] releasing to production is something that is done manually. You can read that on this part of the document above under *Release Branches*:
_Once it's ready to ship, the release gets merged into {{master}} and tagged with a version number._


By the way, on the [Gitflow workflow|https://www.atlassian.com/git/tutorials/comparing-workflows/gitflow-workflow], the {{master}} branch is considered the *Production* branch.
{quote}
fields.summary: Improve Automatic branch merging documentation

fields.description:
You can specify a the set of users and/or groups in the JSON payload when creating/updating "read-only" branch restrictions using POST with the _/rest/branch-permissions/2.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/repos/\{repositorySlug\}/restrictions_ endpoint.

But users and groups are not included in the returned JSON payload using GET with that same endpoint (or the similar _.../restrictions/\{id\}_ endpoint).

Determining the users and groups requires a call to the _/rest/branch-permissions/1.0/projects/\{projectKey\}/repos/\{repositorySlug\}/permitted_ endpoint to determine the users and groups. The inefficiency of requiring a second round trip is compounded by the fact that this is a paged API without an option to search by ID. This would be avoided if users and groups were included in JSON payload returned by the _.../restrictions_ endpoint.
fields.summary: branch-restrictions "restricted" REST endpoint should return users and groups

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Cloning a public repository from a mirror does not work without credentials

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Start Bitbucket Server instance and Mirror
# Create a public repository on the primary
# Sync the repository to the mirror
# Attempt to clone the repository over HTTP without using credentials

h3. Expected Results

The clone succeeds without prompting for credentials.

h3. Actual Results

The clone fails and asks for credentials. Entering valid credentials makes the clone succeed.
 
h3. Cause

This is caused by [validateAuthenticated|https://stash.dev.internal.atlassian.com/projects/STASH/repos/stash/browse/plugins/mirroring-mirror/src/main/java/com/atlassian/bitbucket/internal/mirroring/mirror/DefaultMirroredRepositoryService.java?at=refs%2Ftags%2Fbitbucket-parent-4.3.0#77,108] calls in a mirror specific SCM request check. 

h3.Workaround

Clone from upstream.
fields.summary: Cloning public repositories from a Mirror does not work

fields.description:
*Broken Cases*

* A pull request with four reviewers or less where I am not a reviewer: one of the reviewers are not displayed 
* A pull request with more than four reviewers where I am not a reviewer: two reviewers are displayed and the *+* displayed is missing one reviewer

*Working Cases*
 
* A pull request with three reviewers or less where I am a reviewer: all three reviewers are displayed
* A pull request with more than three reviewers where I am a reviewer: three reviewers and a *+3* are displayed
fields.summary: One reviewer not displayed for pull requests with more than three reviewers of which I am not one

fields.description:
The source view for Bitbucket Server uses automatic line ending detection. That means it searches through the file until it finds the first line ending, notes the type used, and then reads the rest of the file with that line ending.

For files that use consistent line endings (be it old-school Mac-style CR line endings, LF line endings or Windows-style CRLF line endings), the detection means the file displays correctly. However, for files with mixed line endings (regardless of the different types in the mix), only occurrences of the first type found are considered line endings. The rest are stripped, leaving those lines joined.

When blame is displayed for such a file, blame is parsed in a way that explicitly considers _both_ LF and CRLF as line endings (and never considers CR as a line ending). This matches the behavior of {{git blame}}, which always considers LF and CRLF as line endings and doesn't consider CRs. As a result, for mixed line ending files, the blame displayed may not match the line it's displayed on.
fields.summary: Source and blame don't match when a file has mixed LF and CRLF line endings
